FAQ.question: Does an agricultural Sale Deed in AP show land classification?
FAQ.answer: It may mention crop or land classification, but official land type must be verified through revenue records like Adangal and ROR.

FAQ.question: Can agricultural land in Andhra Pradesh be converted to non-agriculture use?
FAQ.answer: Yes, but conversion requires approval from revenue and planning authorities after verifying zoning and land use permissions.

FAQ.question: Does the AP Sale Deed show sub-division numbers for large survey plots?
FAQ.answer: Yes. If the land was divided legally, the document includes sub-division identifiers for each segment.

FAQ.question: Does the Sale Deed confirm pattadar rights?
FAQ.answer: Not always. Pattadar rights appear in revenue records (ROR / Adangal), while Sale Deed proves registered transfer.

FAQ.question: Do banks accept AP agricultural Sale Deeds for loan processing?
FAQ.answer: Yes, but banks may require EC history, Adangal/ROR, tax receipts, and conversion status depending on the loan type.

FAQ.question: Can multiple agricultural plots be included in the same Sale Deed in AP?
FAQ.answer: Yes, if theyâ€™re part of the same transaction and recorded under the same SRO registration.

FAQ.question: Does the Sale Deed show irrigation or borewell rights?
FAQ.answer: Only if registered. Water rights and irrigation access may require separate verification from relevant authorities.

FAQ.question: Can agricultural Sale Deeds be registered without mutation updates?
FAQ.answer: Yes. Registration occurs first. Mutation must be applied separately to update revenue records.

FAQ.question: Does the AP Sale Deed include map or boundary drawings?
FAQ.answer: No, it primarily records survey extent and boundaries textually. FMB or ground survey maps provide actual measurements.

FAQ.question: Is the Sale Deed downloaded from JaaGa authentic?
FAQ.answer: Yes. All records are fetched directly from official AP government registration systems without modification.
